New Records: Luka Modric became the tournament's oldest goalscorer in history and is now just the second player to score at four different European Championship tournaments, along with Cristiano Ronaldo.
Key Match Events: Mattia Zaccagni scored in the final minute of stoppage time to secure a draw for Italy.
Luka Modric scored a goal for Croatia in the 55th minute.
Italy's substitutes played a crucial role in maintaining the balance of the game.
Post-Match Reflections: Italy striker Mateo Retegui expressed great satisfaction with the result, emphasizing the team's personality and resilience.
Italy defender Riccardo Calafiori was very happy and believed the team deserved the goal.
Goalscorer Mattia Zaccagni described his goal as an indescribable emotion.
Croatia defender Marin Pongracic expressed disappointment and the need for deeper analysis of their performance.
Italy boss Luciano Spalletti praised the impact of his substitutes.
Croatia boss Zlatko Dalic expressed his frustration with the added time and emphasized the need for respect for Croatia.
Luka Modric described football as cruel and merciless after Croatia's elimination.
Italy defender Giovanni Di Lorenzo viewed the draw as a starting point for improvement.
Croatia's Luka Ivanusec and Marin Pongracic expressed their disappointment and emptiness after the match.
Miscellaneous Highlights: The manner of Mattia Zaccagni's finish was reminiscent of Alessandro Del Piero's famous goal against Germany in the 2006 World Cup semi-final.
Italy has come from behind to avoid defeat twice in this tournament, a feat they had only achieved twice before in Euros group stage matches.
